pros: Great environment to work in.
cons: "Other duties as assigned" can be overwhelming.

pros: The coworkers are truly good people. And middle management actually does care.
cons: The vision from up top is sooooo hard to see. Morale was very low when I left.

pros: Department always tried to help employee Flexible
cons: I could not find any cons

pros: Work-life balance OK, benefits are decent.
cons: 1. Desperately need a real, professional CIO. Someone who really understands how to build systems that enable productivity. This place is a bunch of disconnected, antiquated systems supported by manual processes. It leads to a lot of employee frustration and dissatisfaction, as well as registrants. 2. They revel in meetings and committees, and get little done. Why? Because when everyone is in charge, no one is. Not every problem needs a committee, it just needs someone willing to be accountable to solve the problem. But, as is often the case in Government, no one wants accountability. 3. Shared services like HR and Marketing are really weak. Turnover, low staffing, and a lack of creativity and entrepreneurship is the culprit. 4. No appreciation for the details from management. Leadership from mid-level and up really don't appreciate the details of day to day processes, and in many cases avoid them like the plague. This leads to apathy and a sense that they don't care about making things better. And some don't.

pros: Great work environment, plenty of free time
cons: Not to many hours to work

pros: Great place to work and live
cons: Salary isn’t enough for the cost of living

pros: As a student, it was a good opportunity to make part time job money.
cons: I didn't really have any cons yet.

pros: The English Language Center has great, positive people working there and incredible in-house training provided. Students are fun to work with as well. There's both in-person and zoom classes to teach which is nice if you don't live close by.
cons: As with any school, lots of time needed the first time you teach a new class.

pros: If you're not part of the LGBTQ community your treated like crap
cons: Treated unfairly, people not made accountable

pros: All the admin and professors are always ready to give you a hand! I love working at HCC. The best place to work!
cons: It is very difficult to get a full-time teaching position.

pros: Admin and staff at HCC are fantastic and always ready to help newcomers. Rich environment to work and learn
cons: Evening classes are scheduled too late.

pros: Benefits such as vacation time and health insurance are great.
cons: This was probably the worst place I've worked at in terms of leadership, including having worked retail. I do believe the lack of leadership is coming from the top down but is worsened by the institution only promoting those that will conform. What HCC says it does and it's actions are completely at odds. Although there are POC at the institution many of them remain in lower positions in spite of having more experience and higher degrees than many in upper management. It is a white female dominated institution and it shows in every way. Incidents of cultural insensitive to colleagues and students make it a toxic place for these individuals. HCC is not open to new ideas which is to the detriment of many of it's employees. No matter how much you are over worked, you will constantly have duties that are outside of your area or responsibility assigned to you without any compensation. President's team is where all the ideas for the institution come from without referring to the people who are actually working in the departments. You end up being forced to comply with ideas that are completely out of touch. Constructive criticism and honest opinions are not welcome which creates a twilight zone like atmosphere where people just pretend everything is okay when it's really not. Seeing what I've seen on the employee side and hearing what I've heard from the student side, make me question how HCC is accredited.

pros: Good place to work and nice salary for entry
cons: no cons, great place to work

review_title: Generally a great place to work, but very focused on image
pros: Committed staff and faculty focused on student success. College leadership places a high value on providing pay increases and avoiding layoffs. Great benefits, including inexpensive healthcare coverage and vacation leave/college breaks. On the higher end of salaries compared to other Maryland colleges. Organization has a good reputation. College structures are in place to promote engagement and transparency. Ice cream party each year the college wins "Best College to Work For."
cons: Work/life balance can be a challenge. If you're not hourly, it's likely you are putting in extra hours on a regular basis. Your quality of life can vary significantly depending on who you are working for, as with anywhere, and there are some leaders at the college who are known to be more challenging to work for. Outside of faculty positions, there are few promotion pathways. The college likes to promote internally but occasionally at the cost of selecting the best person for the job. Image, polish, and reputation appear to be of utmost importance to the leadership, perhaps more so than the actual employee experience, so successful employees are those that toe the line.

job_title: Desktop Support Technician in Columbia, MD
pros: learn new things, easy to understand ticketing system
cons: most students struggle with english

job_title: Assistant Director of Resource Development in Columbia, MD
pros: Excellent health care benefits and generous vacation/PTO/sick time available.
cons: Little opportunity for advancement or promotion.

pros:
The people at HCC are wonderful and the benefits are excellent! Employment is stable and there seem to be lots of opportunities for growth. 

HCC is an employer with a soul. People are not seen as "cogs to get the job done." In fact, though you will probably know a person's name before you know what they actually do ... and you may never know their last name. It's that friendly. 

HCC has worked very hard to make sure its people are taken care of during the pandemic. Many opportunities for improved procedures and processes came out of the closing of campus that HCC seized. 

The population is very diverse and welcoming to people of all backgrounds; international, old, young, various abiliities, etc. There's a lot to do there as a student and employee. 

HCC is w really nice place ot work and has great potential!
cons:
Though the benefits are great, the salaries leave a bit to be desired, especially considering the wealth of the county. If you aren't already working there, or don't know someone, it is really difficult to get full time employment there and the hiring process is painfully slow with strange HR policies (e.g. - people needing to interview for the same position in the same department under a different supervisor.) There is also lots of nepotism and shuffling people around before hiring new people. 

The downside to promotion within is a disconnect from other ways of doing things. Internal processes and workflow are very frustrating and though the optics are there for welcoming feedback, change is VERY slow to the point that some of its systems are downright archaic! Though when forced it navigates changed fairly well (e.g. - a pandemic). 

The lack of relevant training. Lots of sharing of information. But training? Not so much. And Project Management Skills! Though I would hate to see it "lose its soul" to austere business practices, it lacks and could benefit from a bit more operational business savvy. It needs that balance. 

Though the staff and student populations are diverse, leadership and participation in the more prestigious programs lack a bit in representation.

review_title: Admin. HCC- Workplace is good, pay is not so good

pros: Good atmosphere, good location and for the most part- good co-workers.
cons: Primary con: Pay is not even close to what is should be. If you look up the cost of living in Columbia, MD, let alone, any of the surrounding cities/towns, HCC's pay does not pay you a FRACTION of what is actually costs to live in MD.

review_title: Howard Community College is a great place to study and work! Simply the best woking enviornment in Maryland!
job_title: Coordinator of Silas Craft Collegians Program in Columbia, MD
pros: It is a true multicultural environment. Their vision and mission reflects in all their programs held at HCC. The president, staff, and faculty work together as a team to help students acheive their academic goals.  While working at HCC, I acheived intrinsic as well as extrinsic satisfaction.
cons: Once you become part of Howard Community College, it is very difficult to leave and work somewhere else because the working environment is very friendly.

pros: Awesome benefits and wellness program, many incredible  colleagues
cons: The college has grown significantly in the past two decades and has been unable to keep up with that growth in terms of salary, workload, morale, management. The work keeps increasing without more staffing or pay. The current administration pays lip service to their commitment to diversity and their diverse student body. Even though it is an academic institution, many of the departments run top-down. Too many good people are leaving the institution.

pros: The English Language Institute was extremely well organized. We had many adjunct instructors and management was very supportive in terms of resources and materials, training, and mentoring. The instructors were creative, generous with their time and ideas, and helpful. The full-time staff was fantastic.
cons: The nature of being an adjunct is low pay and few to no benefits. This job, despite how great it was, was no exception. Additionally, the nature of teaching requires one to take work home. Here, too, no exception.

pros: Excellent benefits- The health insurance plans offered are fantastic, tons of PTO included unlimited (accrued) sick days. Educational reimbursement is great. There is also a stellar wellness program/ gym on campus.
cons:
Pay- though the benefits balance the low pay. Especially for dual income families. 
Parking is also a bit if a terror, but they are in the process of building a new garage that will hopefully solve the problem. The last issue is upward mobility- as a young professional, there are not many opportunities to grow your career.

pros:
Good benefits if you are budgeted. 
Friendly atmosphere.
Provide PD opportunities with limited resources.
Take care to celebrate successes. 
Competent leadership.
cons:
It can feel like a slow moving cargo ship. Changes occur in a very deliberative way which can be good or bad. 

Things getting a bit top heavy on the staff side of things. Need more folks whose job it is to actually realize the services, not just talk about them in meetings.

pros: Great team, great environment, good place to work. Dual monitors helps you stay organized and efficient. Good to know you've helped student achieve their dreams.

review_title: Solid Spot to Start Hard Place to Grow
pros: Howard Community College has a great environment to work in.  The student body is great to work with.  Plenty of time off and very good health insurance options.
cons: As a staff member it is hard to grow.  There is not a lot of turnover, therefore positions are rarely open.  A lot of times they hire from outside the college instead of promoting within.  Pay is lower than average because it is education field.  Very hard to gain promotion without a Masters degree.

review_title: Very fufilling job with reasonable and helpful manager
pros: The professors and manager were helpful and very nice. A lot of the students were very thankful. The hours were always consistent and the material being reviewed was not at too high of a level.
cons: Some of the students had bad attitudes but this was easily remedied with a positive attitude. Sometimes the tutor to student ratio was a bit off, if more could be afforded it would have been nice having more people work the floor.

pros: Howard Community College provides good staff rapport, international and local flavor, excellent professional training, and programs that provide the most basic to quite advanced training for students.
cons: It is difficult for anyone in a grant funded program to be able to have benefits. That is true across the board in the US.
